questions.text: A young girl presented with delayed puberty. On examination, secondary sexual characters were absent, the nipples were widely spaced, and she was short in height. The most likely karyotype would be? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45XO

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described in the question are characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is caused by the presence of only one X chromosome (45XO karyotype). The key features of Turner syndrome include:

 

  • Delayed puberty and absence of secondary sexual characteristics: Due to ovarian dysgenesis or streak ovaries, which lead to primary ovarian insufficiency.
  • Short stature: Almost all girls with Turner syndrome are short.
  • Widely spaced nipples and shield-like chest: These are typical physical features of Turner syndrome.
  • Webbed neck (common feature).

 

Note - 46XXX: This karyotype, also known as triple X syndrome, typically presents with taller than average stature and normal sexual development, which does not match the described clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The karyotype 45XO is associated with Turner syndrome, which is characterized by delayed puberty, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, short stature, widely spaced nipples, and other distinctive physical features.

questions.text: The abnormal preoperative pulmonary function test in a patient with severe kyphoscoliosis includes: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased RV/TLC

 

Explanation:

 

Severe kyphoscoliosis causes restrictive pathophysiology due to chest wall abnormalities. This condition typically shows a preserved RV but reduced FRC and TLC. With significant respiratory muscle weakness that accompanies severe kyphoscoliosis, the RV is elevated while TLC is reduced. This pattern leads to an increased RV/TLC ratio as the patient cannot fully exhale to normal RV or inhale to normal TLC due to mechanical limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced FEV1/FVC: In restrictive disorders like kyphoscoliosis, the FEV1/FVC ratio is typically normal or increased (not reduced). Reduced FEV1/FVC is characteristic of obstructive disorders like asthma or COPD.

 

Option C. Increased TLC: Kyphoscoliosis causes a reduction in TLC due to mechanical limitation of chest wall expansion. Restrictive disorders have decreased TLC, not increased.

 

Option D. Increased FVC: FVC is reduced in kyphoscoliosis because the restricted chest wall prevents full inspiration. With elevated RV and reduced TLC, the FVC (which equals TLC minus RV) must be reduced, not increased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe kyphoscoliosis produces a restrictive pattern with reduced TLC, reduced FVC, normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, and an increased RV/TLC ratio due to mechanical limitations of the chest wall and associated respiratory muscle weakness.

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) APL and EPB

 

  • Finkelstein test has been shown which helps to diagnose de Quervain’s tenosynovitis (Inflammation of Abductor Pollicis Longus and Extensor Pollicis brevis).

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic.
  • The examiner places patients’ thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction.
  • In positive test, this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the thumb left free is relatively painless.

 

 

  • Differential diagnosis includes scaphoid non-union, arthritis at the base of thumb and intersection syndrome.
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis.
  • The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

Explanation

 

This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.

 

Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.

 

Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incised looking lacerated wound

 

The image shows a lacerated wound which looks like incised wound. This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”. They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

They can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laceration: Irregular tear-like wounds caused by blunt trauma. They often have jagged edges and may have tissue bridges at the base. The wound in the image appears cleaner and more linear, resembling an incised wound, making it an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Clean, straight cuts typically caused by sharp instruments such as knives or glass. The wound in the image is caused by blunt force and has characteristics of a laceration, despite its appearance.

 

Option C. Lacerated looking incised wound:  In areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc, the shapes are zigzag type. So, although it is produced by sharp weapon but it looks like lacerated wound. Such wounds are sometimes called as lacerated looking incised wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An incised looking lacerated wound is caused by blunt force trauma but appears similar to an incised wound due to its location and the characteristics of the tissue involved.

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

 

Explanation:

 

If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.

 

Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

choices.text: Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus
When 02 and CO2 ratio is equal
The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg

questions.text: V/Q = infinity holds true in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Equal to dead space

 

Explanation

 

VA/Q= infinity suggests that Q is 0 which implies that there is no exchange of 02 & CO2, and no gaseous exchange occurs in dead space.

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body obstruction in the bronchus: Incorrect, as this condition would lead to an area with no ventilation (blocked by the foreign body) potentially resulting in a low V/Q ratio in the affected area rather than an infinite V/Q ratio.

 

Option C. When O2 and CO2 ratio is equal: Incorrect, as this does not directly relate to the ventilation-perfusion ratio concept. This option is more a reflection of gas exchange effectiveness rather than a description of V/Q mismatches.

 

Option D. The PO2 of alveolar air is 159 mmHg and PCO2 is 40 mmHg: Incorrect, these values are typical for normal alveolar air and do not indicate a V/Q mismatch situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VA /Q ratio is infinite in the following scenarios -

 

  1. Ventilation is normal but there is no perfusion.
  2. No gaseous exchange through the respiratory membranes of corresponding alveoli.
  3. The alveolar air equilibrates the humidified inspired air.
  4. Partial pressures of the 02 and CO, are 149 mmHg & 0 mm Hg respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aphthous ulcers

 

These are shallow, round ulcers that are often seen in the mouth but can also occur in the small intestine and colon in Crohn's disease. They are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease and are often recurrent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobblestone appearance: This is a characteristic finding in Crohn's disease and refers to the appearance of the mucosa with raised, rounded, and separated areas resembling cobblestones. This is caused by transmural inflammation and can be seen in the terminal ileum and colon.

 

Option B. Deep fissured ulcers: These are another feature of Crohn's disease that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract. They are deep, often extend into the submucosa, and can lead to the formation of fistulas or abscesses.

 

Option C. Rose-thorn appearance: This term is sometimes used to describe the appearance of the mucosa in Crohn's disease, where there are linear ulcers that are surrounded by raised, edematous tissue. This pattern is more commonly seen in the colon.

 

Educational Objective:


Aphthous ulcers are the earliest sign of Crohn's disease, often appearing in the mouth and gastrointestinal tract before more severe lesions develop.

choices.text: Lateral condyle fracture of humerus

questions.text: An 18-year-old child presents with history of fall leading to injury to the right elbow. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial head dislocation

 

RADIAL HEAD DISLOCATION

 

  • Isolated radial head dislocation is uncommon. 
  • It most commonly presents as a partial dislocation or subluxation, also known as nursemaid’s elbow, seen in children.
  • Complete radial head dislocation, although rare, is most commonly associated with high-force injuries of the arm in children as well as in adults and, therefore, is often associated with a forearm fracture or dislocation.
  • The peak incidence is between 4-10 years of age. 
  • Causes:
    • The annular ligament stabilizes the radial head.
    • In the case of subluxation, an axial force on an extended, pronated forearm causes the annular ligament to slip over the radial head.
    • A complete radial head dislocation is most commonly from a high-force injury causing a tear in the annular ligament.
    • Less often, the annular ligament remains intact, connected to the lateral collateral ligament and the ulna, causing the radial head to slip under the annular ligament.
  • On physical examination, the child with a partial displacement protectively holds their arm in an extended and pronated fashion.
  • There is discomfort and pain over the radial head, and the child refuses to use arm by holding it close to body.
  • The patient also resists forearm range of motion testing.
  • A lateral view x-ray of the elbow shows the “ulnar bow sign” seen in isolated radial head dislocation.
  • There is a slight curvature in the ulna on the lateral view.
  • "Isolated" dislocation of the radial head is almost always in fact associated with a bowing fracture of the ulna.

 

Ulnar bow sign

 

  • The lateral humeral line (LHL) is often used to diagnose lateral radial head dislocation on the anterior-posterior x-ray.
  • The LHL is a line drawn along the lateral edge of the lateral condyle parallel to the axis of the distal shaft of the humerus.
  • It typically intersects the lateral cortex of the radial neck.

 

Lateral humeral line

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation: The most common dislocation is posterior or posterolateral and is usually the result of a fall with forearm supinated and the elbow either extended or partially flexed. Simple dislocations result in injuries of the medial and lateral collateral ligament complexes without bony injury. Complex dislocations are associated with fractures about the elbow. Associated soft tissue injuries may involve the brachial artery, ulnar nerve (most commonly), median and radial nerve. Most common joint to dislocate in children (male children in 10-15 years of age group). Most prominent part is olecranon in dislocated elbow. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow with elbow motion painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, and forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiograph shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship.

 

 

Option C. Supracondylar fracture of humerus: Supracondylar humeral fractures in children are most common elbow injuries, especially in children aged 5–8 years. It occurs after a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

The child complains of pain and refusal to move the elbow. On physical examination, there is a gross deformity, swelling, ecchymosis in antecubital fossa, limited active elbow motion.

 

 

Option D. Lateral condyle fracture of humerus: This is a transphyseal intraarticular injury usually involving immature skeleton of children and adolescent. The lateral condylar (or capitellar) epiphysis begins to ossify during the first year of life and fuses with shaft at 12–16 years. Between these ages, it may be sheared off or avulsed by forceful traction. The maximum chances of injury is between 5–15 years. They are the most common distal humeral epiphyseal fractures. Mechanism of fracture is fall on outstretched arm with varus stress that “Pulls off” (avulses) lateral condyle or Valgus force (rarely) in which radial head directly pushes off the lateral condyle. The child comes with lateral elbow pain and swelling. On physical examination, there is no obvious deformity seen. The swelling and tenderness are usually limited to the lateral side. Lateral ecchymosis implies a tear in the aponeurosis of the brachioradialis and signals an unstable fracture. There may be increased pain with resisted wrist extension/flexion. Crepitus may be felt at the fracture site.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the radial head dislocation.
  • Since it is common at the age between 4-10 years, it is the correct diagnosis of the given condition.

questions.text: A vegan lady came with features of anemia. She is likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation:

 

Vegans, who follow a diet that excludes all animal products, are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is primarily found in animal-derived foods such as meat, dairy products, and eggs. Since vegans do not consume these foods, they are prone to developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D deficiency is not specifically related to a vegan diet. While vegans may need to supplement vitamin D from non-animal sources, the question does not provide enough information to suggest that this is the likely deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin A deficiency is also not directly related to a vegan diet. Vegans can obtain sufficient vitamin A from plant-based sources such as leafy green vegetables, carrots, and sweet potatoes.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency is unlikely in a vegan diet, as many fruits and vegetables are rich sources of vitamin C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vegans are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia, as vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal-derived foods.

questions.text: Lysyl oxidase, which is necessary for collagen cross-linking, specifically requires which of the following? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Copper

 

Explanation:

 

Lysyl oxidase is an essential enzyme in collagen maturation that catalyzes the formation of aldehyde groups from lysine residues, which subsequently form cross-links between collagen molecules. This enzyme specifically requires copper as a cofactor for its activity. The copper-dependent nature of lysyl oxidase explains why copper deficiency (as in Menke's disease) leads to defective collagen cross-linking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zinc: While zinc is important for many enzymatic reactions in the body, it is not the specific cofactor required by lysyl oxidase. Zinc is a cofactor for other enzymes like ALA dehydratase in heme synthesis.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron is required for prolyl hydroxylase, another enzyme involved in collagen maturation, but not for lysyl oxidase. Iron is essential for hydroxylation of proline residues in collagen.

 

Option D. Selenium:  Selenium is an essential trace element incorporated into selenoproteins, but it is not required for lysyl oxidase activity. Selenium functions primarily as an antioxidant in proteins like glutathione peroxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper is an essential cofactor for lysyl oxidase, which catalyzes cross-link formation in collagen fibers; copper deficiency (as in Menke's disease) results in impaired collagen maturation characterized by defective cross-linking, leading to symptoms like kinky hair, growth retardation, and connective tissue abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms explains the cerebroprotective effect of Thiopentone? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased cerebral metabolism

 

Thiopentone offers cerebroprotection primarily by reducing cerebral metabolism. It decreases cerebral oxygen consumption (CMO₂), cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), and intracranial tension (ICT). This makes it particularly useful for cerebral protection in cases of focal ischemia, where reducing the brain’s metabolic demands helps limit damage during periods of impaired perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduction of vasospasm: Although thiopentone can have some vascular effects, there is no evidence that it reduces vasospasm. In fact, due to its high alkalinity, intra-arterial injection of thiopentone may actually provoke vasospasm.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blockade: Thiopentone does not act via calcium channels. Its primary mechanism is through potentiation of GABA-A receptors, increasing chloride ion conductance and leading to neuronal hyperpolarization. It also suppresses excitatory neurotransmission.

 

Option D. Free radical removal: There is no indication that thiopentone acts as a free radical scavenger. Its neuroprotective properties are attributed to its ability to decrease metabolic demand in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone provides effective cerebroprotection in focal ischemia by lowering cerebral metabolic rate and oxygen consumption, thus reducing the brain's oxygen demand during compromised blood flow.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with primary infertility is found to have bilateral tubal block on HSG. The next best step is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy with chromotubation

 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is often the first test used to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes in women experiencing infertility. If the HSG reveals a bilateral tubal block, the next best step is to confirm the findings through laparoscopy with chromotubation. This procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the fallopian tubes. Chromotubation involves the injection of a dye through the fallopian tubes to assess their patency directly, which is more accurate than imaging alone. Additionally, if the block is confirmed, there may be an opportunity to address it surgically during the same procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVF: While IVF is a valid treatment option for tubal factor infertility, it is generally considered after confirming the tubal block with laparoscopy. IVF is often chosen if re-canalization attempts fail or if the patient prefers to bypass surgery.

 

Option C. IUI (Intrauterine Insemination): IUI is not suitable in cases of confirmed bilateral tubal block because it requires at least one patent fallopian tube for sperm to reach the egg.

 

Option D. Letrozole: Letrozole is an ovulation induction agent used in women with ovulatory dysfunction. It is not appropriate for treating tubal block issues and thus is not relevant in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After identifying a bilateral tubal block on HSG in a woman with primary infertility, the next best step is to confirm the diagnosis with laparoscopy and chromotubation before considering other treatments like IVF.

questions.text: Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

  • The given clinical scenario with a diagnosis of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) points to amniotic fluid embolism as the most likely etiology.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism presents as 
    • hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC.
    • Usually, it presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum.
    • Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features.

 

Diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

 

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever ≥38°C

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Postpartum haemorrhage: This will present as vaginal bleeding followed by collapse/ DIC

 

Option C. Eclampsia: This will present as seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: This will present as cardiac failure following delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collapse in a patient during labor/ delivery followed by bleeding and DIC in the absence of coexisting conditions is most likely due to amniotic fluid embolism.

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4th degree


Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of tissue damage during childbirth:

 

  1. 1st degree: Involves only the vaginal mucosa or skin of the perineum without involving deeper tissues.
  2. 2nd degree: Extends deeper, involving the perineal muscles but does not reach the anal sphincters; similar to an episiotomy.
  3. 3rd degree: Involves the anal sphincter complex with further sub-classifications:
    • 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3b: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3c: Both the external and internal anal sphincters are involved.
  4. 4th degree: Extends through the rectal mucosa, completely disrupting the sphincters and the rectal lining.

 

Since the tear extends to the rectum, this is classified as a 4th degree tear, the most severe type, involving the entire perineum, anal sphincters, and rectal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:


A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

choices.text: Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency
Vitamin D deficiency
P. alba (Pityriasis alba)

questions.text: Identify the image and it is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency

 

Casal necklace is a dermatological manifestation observed in pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. It presents as a symmetrical rash around the neck region. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis often appears in sun-exposed areas, resulting in the distinctive Casal necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to rickets, a condition characterized by soft, weak bones and skeletal deformities such as bowed legs and widened wrists. The image described does not depict these skeletal changes.

 

Option C. Rickets: Rickets is associated with Vitamin D deficiency and presents with skeletal abnormalities like bowed legs, widened wrists, and delayed growth. The image does not show these features, ruling out rickets as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. P. alba (Pityriasis alba): P. alba, also known as pityriasis alba, is a skin condition characterized by small, raised, white or flesh-colored bumps on the skin, typically affecting children. It is not associated with a specific vitamin deficiency but rather with blocked sweat ducts. The image described in the question is not consistent with pityriasis alba.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal necklace is a classic dermatological manifestation of pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of respiratory depression and is suspected of having overdosed on opioids. What should be the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Naloxone

 

In a patient presenting with symptoms of respiratory depression suspected to be due to an opioid overdose, the immediate next step in management should be the administration of Naloxone. Naloxone is an opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose, particularly life-threatening respiratory depression. It acts quickly and is typically administered intravenously, intramuscularly, or via nasal spray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naltrexone: While Naltrexone is also an opioid antagonist, it is used primarily for the long-term management of alcohol and opioid dependence, rather than for the acute reversal of opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in the treatment of opioid dependence. It is not suitable for the immediate treatment of opioid overdose and its respiratory depressant effects.

 

Option D. Methadone: Methadone is a long-acting opioid used in the maintenance treatment of opioid dependence and chronic pain management. It is not used for the treatment of acute opioid overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of suspected opioid overdose, particularly with signs of respiratory depression, the administration of Naloxone is the immediate and appropriate intervention. Naloxone acts as an opioid antagonist and can rapidly reverse the life-threatening effects of opioid overdose.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 293.

questions.text: Bubo seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphogranuloma venereum

 

Explanation:

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3.

 

A bubo refers to an inflamed, swollen lymph node, often filled with pus. In LGV, this typically presents as inguinal lymphadenitis with pus formation, which is a key characteristic feature.

 

 

Another important sexually transmitted disease associated with bubo formation is chancroid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. Granuloma inguinale: Also known as donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with subcutaneous nodules in the inguinal region but does not involve lymphadenopathy. These nodules are sometimes referred to as pseudo-bubo because of their superficial similarity to buboes, but they do not have the same pathophysiology.

 

Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea typically presents with urethral discharge and does not cause bubo formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bubo is a characteristic feature of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and chancroid, involving inflamed, pus-filled lymph nodes, particularly in the inguinal region. ​

questions.text: Which of the following cutaneous malignancies does not metastasize through the lymphatics? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is characterized by its inability to metastasize through lymphatic channels. BCC "destroys the lymphatics and vessels" and demonstrates "no lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis." BCCs are locally invasive tumors that produce type IV collagenase (particularly the morphoeic type), which allows them to invade surrounding tissues, but they rarely spread beyond their primary site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma - Incorrect. SCCs and can metastasize through lymphatic channels as part of their natural history. The overall rate of metastasis is 2% for SCC, usually to regional nodes.

 

Option C. Melanoma - Incorrect. Melanoma is highly aggressive and readily metastasizes through lymphatics. The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index in melanoma. The staging of melanoma (TNM) explicitly includes nodal status.

 

Option D. Kaposi's sarcoma - Incorrect. Kaposi's sarcoma is a malignant, proliferative tumor of vascular endothelial cells that can spread through lymphatic channels. It usually starts as a red-brown, indurated, plaque-like skin lesion that becomes nodular and then ulcerates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Basal cell carcinoma is unique among skin malignancies for its lack of lymphatic metastasis, despite its locally invasive nature through collagenase production.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules. Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

questions.text: The endotoxin of which gram-negative bacterium does not play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease it causes? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Vibrio cholerae

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae is the correct answer because unlike typical Gram-negative infections, the pathogenesis of cholera is primarily mediated by an exotoxin (cholera toxin) rather than its endotoxin. Cholera toxin activates adenylate cyclase in intestinal epithelial cells, leading to massive secretion of water and electrolytes, resulting in the characteristic profuse, watery "rice-water" diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli - The endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) of E. coli plays a significant role in its pathogenesis, particularly in septic shock. The endotoxin activates inflammatory pathways, complement cascades, and can lead to fever, hypotension, and disseminated intravascular coagulation.

 

Option B. Klebsiella - The endotoxin of Klebsiella is a major virulence factor in its pathogenesis. During infection, Klebsiella's endotoxin contributes to the inflammatory response, potential septic shock, and tissue damage.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa - Endotoxin plays an important role in Pseudomonas infections. The lipopolysaccharide component of P. aeruginosa activates inflammatory responses contributing to tissue damage and systemic effects during infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While all Gram-negative bacteria contain endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide) in their cell walls, the relative importance of this component in disease pathogenesis varies. For Vibrio cholerae, the exotoxin (cholera toxin) is the primary virulence factor responsible for the characteristic clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with black deposit in the vertebrae visible on X-Ray LS spine and also over knee joint and sclera which shows ochronosis. Which enzyme deficiency has caused this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisic acid oxidase

 

The clinical presentation describes Alkaptonuria, which is caused by deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase (also known as homogentisate dioxygenase). This is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by:

 

  • Accumulation of homogentisic acid which gets oxidized to form black colored alkapton bodies
  • These alkapton bodies deposit in various tissues causing ochronosis: 
    • Sclera (causing black discoloration)
    • Cartilage of joints (causing arthritis)
    • Vertebral column (visible on X-ray)
    • Skin showing bluish-black color
  • The condition typically presents in adults around 30-40 years
  • Homogentisic acid gets excreted in urine, causing urine to turn black on standing (characteristic feature)
  • FeCl3 test of urine is positive
  • Part of Garrod's tetrad (along with albinism, cystinuria, and pentosuria)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency: Causes phenylketonuria (PKU) characterized by mental retardation, musty odor, and hypopigmentation. Does not cause ochronosis.

 

Option C. Tyrosine transaminase deficiency: Causes tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) characterized by corneal ulcers and hyperkeratotic plaques. No ochronosis.

 

Option D. PHPP (para-hydroxy phenyl pyruvate) dioxygenase deficiency: Causes tyrosinemia type III characterized by mental retardation and ataxia but no ochronosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency and presents with ochronosis (black deposits in connective tissues) and darkening of urine on standing.

questions.text: What does the term "aspermia" specifically refer to? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Absence of semen

 

Aspermia specifically refers to the failure of emission of semen (no ejaculate). This represents a condition where there is complete absence of ejaculate during sexual activity, distinct from other sperm or semen abnormalities. It's categorized under post-testicular causes of male infertility and affects the emission phase of ejaculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Absence of sperm in ejaculate: This is incorrect as it describes azoospermia, not aspermia. Azoospermia means there is semen but it contains no spermatozoa.

 

Option C. Absence of sperm motility: This is incorrect as it describes asthenozoospermia or necrozoospermia. Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility, while necrozoospermia refers to spermatozoa that are dead or motionless.

 

Option D. Occurrence of abnormal sperm: This is incorrect as it describes teratozoospermia, which is defined as a high percentage (>70%) of spermatozoa with abnormal morphology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspermia specifically refers to the complete absence of semen ejaculate, representing a failure of emission, which differs from conditions affecting sperm quality or quantity within the ejaculate.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produce urease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Helicobacter pylori

 

Helicobacter pylori is well-known for its ability to produce urease, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of urea into carbon dioxide and ammonia. This enzymatic activity is crucial for the survival of H. pylori in the acidic environment of the stomach. By producing ammonia, H. pylori can neutralize the acidity around it, creating a more hospitable environment for itself and contributing to its pathogenicity, which is associated with gastric ulcers and chronic gastritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella does not produce urease and is known for causing foodborne illnesses primarily affecting the intestinal tract.

 

Option C. Escherichia coli: Incorrect, while some strains of E. coli can produce urease, it is not a characteristic feature, and they are primarily known for other virulence factors.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella does not produce urease and is known for causing dysentery or shigellosis through invasion and inflammation of the intestinal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urease-producing organisms: (Mnemonic-PUNCH)

 

  • Proteus
  • asma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum
  •  H. pylori

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dL) and LDL 220 mg/dL were found to be raised. What is the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LDL receptors defect

 

The patient's symptoms of multiple tendon xanthomas, elevated serum cholesterol, and high LDL levels indicate Type II hyperlipoproteinemia, commonly known as familial hypercholesterolemia. This condition is primarily caused by a defect in LDL receptors, leading to impaired clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The resulting elevated LDL levels promote cholesterol deposition in tendons, forming xanthomas. Treatment typically focuses on reducing LDL cholesterol levels through diet, medication, or in severe cases, LDL apheresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: This defect leads to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by high levels of chylomicrons and triglycerides, but not elevated LDL or cholesterol. Symptoms typically include pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Apo E defect: Apo E defect leads to Type III hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as dysbetalipoproteinemia. This condition is associated with elevated remnants of chylomicrons and VLDL, resulting in palmar xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas, and does not specifically cause the high LDL levels seen in this patient.

 

Option D. LCAT deficiency: LCAT deficiency affects HDL cholesterol conversion to cholesterol esters and does not directly affect LDL levels. It is associated with conditions such as Norum disease or fish eye disease, presenting with corneal opacity and hemolytic anemia rather than tendon xanthomas or elevated LDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDL receptor defects cause familial hypercholesterolemia, characterized by elevated LDL, cholesterol levels, and tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

choices.text: Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy
Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong regarding Weber's syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face

 

LMN Facial palsy occurs in pontine/infra-pontine syndromes.

 

WEBER'S SYNDROME

 

Infarction - Ipsilateral subthalamus and medial thalamus injury with ipsilateral cerebral peduncle and mid- brain lesions.

 

Involvement:

 

  • Third nerve palsy with contralateral hemiplegia (localized to the cerebral peduncle).
  • Subthalamic nucleus - Contralateral hemiballismus
  • Occlusion of the artery of Percheron - Paresis of upward gaze and drowsiness
  • If bilateral proximal PCA occlusion - coma, unreactive pupils, bilateral pyramidal signs, and decerebrate rigidity.

 

Note: A Third nerve palsy with contralateral ataxia - Claude's syndrome. The ataxia indicates involvement of the red nucleus or dentato-rubro-thalamic tract.

 

  • Weber, claude, benedict are medial brainstem syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contralateral hemiplegia: Correct for Weber's syndrome, as it involves the cerebral peduncle, affecting motor pathways that result in weakness on the opposite side of the body.

 

Option B. Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy: Also correct, reflecting the typical involvement of the third cranial nerve, which controls eye movements, eyelid opening, pupil constriction, and most of the eye's focusing muscles.

 

Option C. Contralateral Parkinsonism: While not classically described as a symptom of Weber’s syndrome, it could theoretically relate to potential involvement of nearby structures influencing motor function. However, it is less specific and not as classic a presentation as contralateral hemiplegia and ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weber’s syndrome involves ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiplegia due to midbrain lesions, and does not typically include ipsilateral facial paralysis, which is associated with pontine lesions.

questions.text: Name the investigation shown in the given image?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Conventional HSG

 

Hysterosalpingography

 

  • Hysterosalpingography is the fluoroscopic examination commonly used in the investigations of infertility to assess uterine morphology and tubal patency.
  • The best time to investigate is during the 6th to 10th day of menstrual cycle (not to be done during menstruation; risk of damage to undiagnosed pregnancy after 10th day)
  • A radiopaque dye is injected through the Leech-Wilkinson or Rubin's cannula, or Foley's catheter into the uterine cavity under direct vision with fluoroscopic screen.
  • If the tubes are patent, the medium is usually adequate to exit through the abdominal ostia and smear the adjacent bowel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MR HSG: Involves the use of magnetic resonance imaging to view the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes, not compatible with the use of traditional radiopaque dyes and does not involve real-time fluoroscopy.

 

Option B. CT HSG: Utilizes computed tomography, which is less common and not shown in the image due to the distinct fluoroscopic appearance of conventional HSG.

 

Option D. USG HSG: Ultrasound HSG, also known as sonohysterography, uses ultrasound technology to evaluate the uterus and fallopian tubes, which would not display the classic radiopaque dye pattern seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conventional HSG is a critical diagnostic tool in the assessment of uterine structure and tubal patency, using a radiopaque dye visualized with fluoroscopy, particularly useful in the workup of infertility.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with an ulcerative lesion near the medial canthus of his eye, featuring pearly margins. Microscopic examination reveals a palisading arrangement of cells, along with keratin pearls. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal cell carcinoma

 

The clinical presentation of an ulcerative lesion with pearly margins in the medial canthus (inner corner) of the eye is highly characteristic of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). This location is a common site for BCC, which is also known as "rodent ulcer" or "tear cancer" due to its predilection for the periocular region. The microscopic finding of palisading arrangement of cells is a hallmark feature of BCC, where the peripheral cells arrange themselves in a palisade-like pattern. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoacanthoma: Incorrect. While keratoacanthoma may present as an ulcerative lesion, it typically has a central keratin-filled crater rather than pearly margins. It usually grows rapidly over a few weeks and is most commonly found on sun-exposed areas like the face, forearms, and hands. It lacks the characteristic palisading arrangement seen in this case.

 

Option B. Melanocytic melanoma: Incorrect. Melanoma presents as a pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variations. It does not typically have pearly margins or palisading arrangement of cells on microscopy. Instead, it shows atypical melanocytes with nuclear pleomorphism and invasion.

 

Option C. Squamous cell carcinoma: Incorrect. While squamous cell carcinoma can present as an ulcerative lesion and does feature keratin pearls microscopically, it typically lacks the pearly margins described in this case. Additionally, the palisading arrangement of cells is not characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma but is a hallmark feature of basal cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma presenting as an ulcerative lesion with pearly margins (rodent ulcer) is characteristic, especially in the periocular region, with microscopic findings of peripheral palisading arrangement of basaloid cells.

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidural anesthesia

 

The best type of anesthesia for pre-eclampsia is Epidural anesthesia (Option B).

 

Epidural anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic agents into the epidural space of the spine. It can be titrated to the desired level of anesthesia/analgesia and can be maintained for longer periods. 

 

  • Key Advantages in the context of pre-eclampsia:
    • Avoidance of airway manipulation: As mentioned, pregnancy can present with airway challenges due to edema, short neck, and increased breast size.
    • Preservation of Airway Reflexes: There's no risk of aspiration, which is a concern in pregnant patients due to delayed gastric emptying.
    • Decreased drug passage to fetus: Fewer systemic drugs are used, which reduces the risk of placental transfer and potential neonatal depression.
    • Pain management: Effective pain control can help in reducing catecholamine levels, which can otherwise increase blood pressure further in pre-eclamptic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal anesthesia:

 

While it provides rapid and effective anesthesia for surgeries below the abdomen, it may cause a significant drop in blood pressure, which can be concerning in patients with pre-eclampsia.

 

Option C. General anesthesia:

 

In pregnant patients, especially with conditions like pre-eclampsia, general anesthesia presents multiple challenges:

 

Airway difficulties

 

Risk of aspiration: Pregnant patients are at an increased risk of aspiration during induction and intubation due to delayed gastric emptying.

 

Drug transfer to fetus: Many anesthetic agents can cross the placenta, potentially affecting the fetus.

 

Option D. Caudal block:

 

A caudal block is a type of epidural where the anesthetic is administered at the sacral hiatus. It's typically used in pediatric patients . While it can provide good analgesia, it's not the primary choice for managing pre-eclampsia in obstetric procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural anesthesia is preferred for pre-eclampsia due to its ability to provide effective pain relief, avoid airway manipulation, and minimize drug passage to the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is primarily found in the extracellular matrix?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Collagen

 

Explanation: 

 

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the extracellular matrix (ECM) and forms the primary structural component. It provides tensile strength and functions as a scaffolding for cells and tissues. Collagens are composed of three separate polypeptide chains braided into a triple helix structure. There are about 30 different collagen types identified, with types I, II, III, and V forming linear fibrils that comprise a major proportion of connective tissue in bone, tendon, cartilage, blood vessels, and skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrin - While fibrin can be found in the ECM during wound healing, it is not primarily an ECM component. Fibrin is formed from fibrinogen during blood clotting and is a key component of blood clots rather than normal ECM.

 

Option C. Fibrillin - Though fibrillin is indeed an ECM component, it is not as abundant as collagen. Fibrillin forms microfibrils that provide structural support for elastic fibers and is associated with elastin in tissues requiring elasticity, like blood vessels and skin.

 

Option D. Proteoglycan - Proteoglycans are important components of the ECM, consisting of a core protein with attached glycosaminoglycan chains. While they are significant ECM constituents that contribute to compressibility and lubrication, they are not as abundant as collagen, which makes up approximately 30% of the total protein in the human body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Collagen is the most abundant and primary structural protein in the extracellular matrix, providing essential tensile strength and scaffolding for tissues throughout the body.

questions.text: Which of the options was initiated to ensure complete immunization of children? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MISSION INDRADHANUSH INCLUDES

 

  1. Polio
  2. Diphtheria
  3. Pertussis
  4. Tetanus
  5. TB
  6. Measles
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Rota Virus
  9. MR
  10. IPV
  11. JE
  12. HiB
  13. PCV

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen.  On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.

 

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.

 

IMPERFORATE HYMEN

 

  • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision.

 

 

In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse vaginal septum: Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI

 

Option B. Vaginal atresia: If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

questions.text: The number of Barr bodies in Klinefelter’s syndrome is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. 1

 

Explanation: 

 

In Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY), there is one Barr body. The number of Barr bodies follows the formula of the number of X chromosomes minus one (X-1). Since Klinefelter syndrome patients have two X chromosomes (XXY), they have one Barr body (2-1=1). This is a phenotypically male condition that is the most common genetic cause of male infertility, characterized by testicular atrophy, decreased testosterone, increased FSH/LH, gynecomastia, and tall stature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0 - This is incorrect for Klinefelter syndrome. Normal males (XY) and Turner syndrome patients (XO) have zero Barr bodies because they only have one X chromosome (1-1=0).

 

Option C. 2 - This would be found in a 47,XXX karyotype (Triple X syndrome or "Superfemale"), where three X chromosomes are present, resulting in two Barr bodies (3-1=2).

 

Option D. 3 - This would be found in a female with four X chromosomes (e.g., 48,XXXX), which is extremely rare. The number of Barr bodies would be three (4-1=3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The number of Barr bodies follows the simple formula (X-1), where Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) has one Barr body, normal females (46,XX) have one Barr body, and normal males (46,XY) have zero Barr bodies.

choices.text: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

questions.text: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasions

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two different ova released in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse occurring within a short period of time. This can result in twins with different fathers if the sperm comes from two different men, a phenomenon known as heteropaternal superfecundation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse: This describes the fertilization of two ova by sperm from a single act of intercourse, which is not superfecundation but simply the result of one intercourse fertilizing two ova simultaneously.

 

Option C. Both of the above: While it includes the correct scenario of superfecundation, it also includes an incorrect scenario, making it partially correct.

 

Option D. None of the above: This indicates that none of the given scenarios are correct, which is inaccurate as option B is correct.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova released during the same menstrual cycle by sperm from separate acts of intercourse.

 

Ref: Page 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A truck driver came with painful genital ulcer and lymph nodes. H/O unprotected sex present. Choose the correct clinical condition: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chancroid

 

Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful genital ulcers and painful lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes). The history of unprotected sexual intercourse and the clinical presentation of painful genital ulcers and painful lymph nodes strongly suggest chancroid.

 

  1. Painful genital ulcers: Chancroid typically presents with painful ulcers on the genitalia. These ulcers can be multiple and have irregular, undermined edges.
  2. Painful lymph nodes: The infection often leads to painful, swollen lymph nodes in the inguinal region, which can sometimes suppurate and form buboes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily, not typically associated with painful lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Chancre: A chancre is a painless ulcer that is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. It does not fit the description of painful ulcers and painful lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Herpes: Genital herpes, caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), presents with painful vesicles that evolve into ulcers. However, the presence of vesicles, rather than ulcers initially, distinguishes herpes from chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Anticancer drug that can result in hand and foot syndrome is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Capecitabine is an oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and both of these drugs are known to cause hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia). This condition is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It occurs due to the leakage of the drug from capillaries in these areas, leading to skin toxicity. Hand-foot syndrome is a well-documented adverse effect of capecitabine, making it the correct answer in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is associated with a different side effect profile, most notably hemorrhagic cystitis, which can be prevented by the administration of mesna.

 

Option B. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis and can also result in flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: Paclitaxel is an anticancer drug that primarily causes peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine & 5FU can cause hand-foot syndrome, which is an important side effect to monitor in patients receiving this treatment.

questions.text: Thrombosis of posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral Medullary syndrome.

 

LATERAL MEDULLARY SYNDROME:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Weber is a medial midbrain syndrome caused by occlusion of PCA branches.

 

Option C: Medial medullary syndrome (aka Dejerine syndrome) supplied by vertebral/spinal artery.

 

Option D: Millard-Gubler is a lateral pontine syndrome involving peripheral LMN of 7th and 6th nerve (NOT NUCLEUS!) supplied by AICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Image showing arteries involved in brainstem syndromes lateral vs medial brainstem.

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Chap 426/Neurology/stroke

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

 

Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

 

On light microscopy, characteristic feature is no apparent abnormality in the glomeruli except for slight increase in the mesangial matrix at the most.

 

 

By electron microscopy, the most characteristic feature of the disease is identified which is diffuse flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and, hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.

 

In contrast to other types of GN, no deposits are visible, and the GBM is normal. No complement or immunoglobulin deposits are detected using immunofluorescence microscopy (nil deposit disease).

 

It's also seen in other diseases like membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. These diseases are also known as podocytopathies because they affect podocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroid resistant glomerulonephritis: This term is more of a clinical description rather than a specific pathological diagnosis. Steroid-resistant cases can include various glomerulonephritis types such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which also shows podocyte effacement but is not the classic example of it.

 

Option C. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is associated with severe glomerular damage and rapid loss of kidney function. It does not specifically show effacement of podocyte foot processes as its primary feature.

 

Option D. Chronic glomerulonephritis: Chronic glomerulonephritis encompasses various forms of long-standing glomerular diseases leading to chronic kidney damage. It is associated with glomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis but not specifically with podocyte foot process effacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

choices.text: Bone marrow aspirate
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
Polymerase chain reaction

questions.text: A 62-year-old elderly male presented with persistent fatigue and lymph total leucocyte count of 50,000/µl. His peripheral smear was done and had the findings as shown. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

The given history of elderly male with leucocytosis and the peripheral smear showing “smudge cells” is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The diagnosis of CLL can be confirmed using flow cytometry demonstrating cells with CD5/CD23 expression.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow aspirate: While useful in some cases, it is not necessary for the initial diagnosis of CLL if flow cytometry can provide definitive results.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is useful for detecting specific genetic abnormalities but is not the first step in confirming CLL.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR can detect specific genetic mutations but is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a suspected case of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), especially with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, flow cytometry is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient underwent uneventful phacoemulsification with IOL implantation. On the third postoperative day, he presented with pain, diminished vision, redness, watering, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reflex. Examination revealed circumcorneal congestion, aqueous cells 4+, hypopyon in the anterior chamber, posterior synechiae, and retrolental flare. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endophthalmitis

 

This case presents a classic picture of bacterial endophthalmitis following cataract surgery. The presentation on postoperative day three with severe pain, marked diminution of vision, circumcorneal congestion, hypopyon, and a grayish-yellow pupillary reflex are hallmark signs. Bacterial endophthalmitis typically presents between 48-72 hours after surgery with precisely these symptoms and signs.

 

This is an emergency complication of cataract surgery with an incidence of 0.1-0.5%. The symptoms and signs typically present between 48-72 hours after surgery and include ocular pain, diminished vision, lid edema, conjunctival chemosis, marked circumciliary congestion, corneal edema, exudates in pupillary area, hypopyon, and diminished or absent red pupillary glow. This exactly matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratitis: Incorrect. While keratitis (corneal inflammation) can cause pain, redness and diminished vision, it would primarily present with corneal findings such as infiltrates, epithelial defects, or corneal edema. The presentation with hypopyon, aqueous cells, posterior synechiae, and grayish-yellow pupillary reflex points to a more extensive intraocular inflammation.

 

Option B. Glaucoma: Incorrect. Postoperative glaucoma may cause pain and diminished vision, but it wouldn't explain the marked inflammatory signs including hypopyon, posterior synechiae, and significant aqueous cells. The grayish-yellow pupillary reflex also wouldn't be a feature of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Iridocorneal Cyclitis: Incorrect. While this would cause inflammation of the iris and ciliary body with pain and anterior chamber reaction, it typically wouldn't present with the severity described, especially the grayish-yellow pupillary reflex which suggests vitreous involvement. Postoperative anterior uveitis is typically less severe than the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bacterial endophthalmitis following cataract surgery is an emergency characterized by presenting 48-72 hours postoperatively with severe pain, marked visual loss, hypopyon, and exudates in the pupillary area requiring immediate intervention with intravitreal antibiotics.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

The presence of a diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space (Erb's point) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation occurs when the aortic valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: This condition produces a systolic ejection murmur, typically heard at the right second intercostal space.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Regurgitation is associated with a diastolic murmur, best heard at Erb’s point (left 3rd intercostal space). The murmur is typically described as a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh- negative sensitized mother? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCA doppler peak systolic velocity

 

Explanation:

 

  • A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia
  • An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA
  • In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biophysical Profile: Biophysical Profile is a test of antepartum fetal assessment

 

Option B. Fetal blood sampling or Cordocentesis: This is done only when the fetal MCA doppler shows a peak systolic velocity of > 1.5 MoMs

 

Option C. Amnio-spectrometry: This is no longer done as it is an invasive method of measuring the amount of bilirubin in the amniotic fluid to determine the level of fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCA Doppler peak systolic velocity is used to monitor fetal anemia in Rh-negative sensitized mothers due to its non-invasive nature.

 

Ref: Page no 931, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition
